comments.commentBody:
Very disturbing and saddening to read about these fine reporters' experiences, especially the woman photographer. And what must be the death of the driver. Personally, I don't know how any of them, after having been kidnapped before, were able to return to this kind of dangerous journalism. I hope they are able to recover and continue with stories and photography, but without risking their lives or safety. I don't want to read stories that were attained at such high costs to the journalists and any other companions.

That being said, this is one more military enterprise we should not be undertaking. One more military enterprise driving yet another troubled country into further destruction and civil war. How can anyone think otherwise, after what has happened in Iraq and Afghanistan?

Nor can we afford this stuff. As I was driving past a busy traffic corner in my small city today, a few hardy souls stood there with a huge banner sign facing motorists that said (something like), "How's That Military Economy Going For You?"

The M.I.C. is sucking the very life out of the United States. It is so irrational in light of what we should know that it is very, very scary.
Juvenile myasthenia gravis
A mitochondrial myopathy, associated with alopecia.
rhabdomyals is the correct diagnosis

I work with patients each day who struggle with regret over life decisions, usually ones that have been self-destructive (e.g., addictions) or, more often, self-sabotaging (e.g., ending up in bad relationships over and over or failing to reach one's potential). I think there is a continuum--normal, every day regrets like missing out on a great sales event, to deep regrets that are often mixed with self-loathing and difficulty grieving lost opportunities. I have found that when regret cannot be handled alone or in talking with friends, a therapeutic experience like being part of a support group, having individual therapy, or a mixture of the two can help people work through regrets and find greater peace. I think one of the most important aspects of dealing with regret is to remember to be compassionate with ourselves. I try to remind myself of this daily. It is very human to make mistakes; if we get stuck repeating mistakes, we may need help getting unstuck, and that is human too.

We cracked down in Colombia, and the cartels moved to Mexico. They're cracking down there, and now they're moving elsewhere.

We keep slapping band-aids on a problem that requires surgery. Legalization is the only long term viable solution.

You cannot be neutral in such situation. They should communicate w/the rebels and stop playing these diplomatic and political games which are actually endangering the civilians in that they are not acting promptly enough to, for example, take down the snipers on roofs that leave dozens dead. On the contrary, it is in everyone's interest to have a positive impact and outcome. For that reason the "allies" should most definitely coordinate w/the rebels, as they did w/the Kurds
in Iraq. Trying to remain aloof or neutral just doesn't cut it. Gaddafi's forces are mowing down people, terrorizing them, leaving them w/out food, water, electricity, and even commandeering the hospital in Misurata such that they have asked for a medical ship to be sent to the port. These are the messages one should be heeding, and not think about what is happening in the murderer's camp. I urge them to contact the rebels. Totally ridiculous way to win a war. It is either sink or swim, but you have to be totally dedicated to help these rebels and
stop this genocidal madman, or the effort will have failed. One has to
be single-minded to overcome evil of this magnitude. I pray to G-d that the
Americans and others see sense and coordinate w/the rebels. The slaughter is continuing and therefore, Mrs. Clinton,
you have partially averted disaster in one area, only to let it rain down in other areas.
Please do not be afraid to be more pro-active. It is costing thousands of lives.

AM (#45):

YOU WROTE: "Easy to get in, hard to get out. Can't you all see this is a trap set up by the Russians and the Chinese? They didn't veto the UN resolution because they want to see us bogged down and distracted in another mess while they build their economy using resources secured by our sweat and blood. All our dumbwit elected officials were so happy to oblige."

REPLY: I must say this is an impressive observation. I'd been thankful that the Russians and the Chinese (not to mention the Germans, Indians and Brazilians) abstained, but was disappointed that they didn't also veto the resolution. You've offered a convincing explanation.

I think House Majority Leader Boehner is asking the right questions, but he should be asking them in secret, not broadcasting them to the cheap seats.

If only the Republicans had asked this sort of question before we pulled troops out of Afghanistan for their peerless leader's adventure in Iraq, we might have $1.5 trillion less money spent and how many hundred thousand fewer wounded or dead brave soldiers?

However, if any of you nitwits actually expect the U.S. military to post its exit plans and desired outcomes on the web at this point ... I mean, what is the matter with you? Boeher should be going to the White House for a briefing if he is a loyal American congressional leader, not questioning the Commander in Chief in public like some first-year back-bench yahoo from Podunk, Utah.

Will the strategy work? Bombing didn't work in Vietnam. It did work in Kosovo. A couple thousand more soldiers on the ground at Tora Bora would have cut the Afghan war short by 98%. 150,000 soldiers on the ground in Iraq and what do we have now...Uncertainty whether it's a democracy or a state under the influence of Iran.

I am content to let the U.S. military work its magic as long as this commitment remains limited. I trust our military.

How the heck can any of you speak with such certainty after such a small military investment so far in Libya (Yes, small...Iraq: $1.5 trillion...Libya so far: 3/4 of one ten thousandth of that amount and no lost lives. Tiny investment so far.)

I know why all of you are so sure. Because you don't know a thing, and you're frustrated and you have to yell at someone.

Thank you #147 and #177 for telling it like it exactly is.  I can't imagine what Mr. Obama was thinking in falling over himself to get our country involved in this nonsense.  The answer, I have said from the start, is not the grandiose notion of saving Libyan civilians.  The reason is indeed oil.  I am sorry to see that the President has stooped to the disastrous Bush/Cheney answer to everything--If it moves, destroy it; if it ain't moving, destroy that too. Now we are in North Africa as well as the Middle East and we should be doing more here at home, like employing the unemployed, feeding the hungry, showing tolerance to minorities, providing a resonable and affordable health care to the poor or soon to be poor, etc.

To all you naysayers out there, both on the left and the right, don't you realize that by denouncing Obama's decision to intervene in Libya, you are countenancing the slaughter of thousands of innocent people at the hands of Qaddafi's murderous thugs? Are you OK with that? Are you OK with Qaddafi remaining in power? Are you OK with sending the message to all the tyrants out there that as long as you hang tough and fire antiaircraft machine guns at crowds of protesters, you will be OK? Iran, North Korea, etc rejoice at your logic. Please think through the implications.
There are major risks for us in Libya, no question about it, but I predict that things will go our way this time around: Qaddafi's regime will soon collapse and American credit will be at least partly restored in the Middle East and the world at large. This may yet be the best foreign policy decision that Obama has made. So far the administration has played its hand masterfully.
I neglected to mention that Accutane cream from mom's hands could also account for the "funny way of running" due to the impact on long bone growth.
I didn't read all of the comments, but my guess is hereditary inclusion body myopathy, although she's a bit young for that disease. It would be interesting to know her ethnic background.
A.L.T. and A.S.T? I don't think so. Those letters don't actually stand for anything. Should be plain old ALT and AST, or write out the words (alanine aminotransferase does not shorten down to A.L.T.)

Rhabdomyosarcoma?  Damage to muscle from a tumor could result in elevated CPK levels.  Is the filtering function of the liver affected by damaged muscle cells and is that the cause of increased liver enzymes?  According to PubMed, diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma can be delayed to due a lack of symptoms and it's the most common soft tissue tumor in children.  Doesn't explain the hair loss though....

As commented yesterday, once again I do not see other Arab leadership coming out into the street to prevent Khadaffi from bring ousted or run over by his own people. The best outcome is all Libyan leadership takes an action path that is in the best interests of all Libyan people for their future with expanded freedoms creating a higher quality of life for the country. There is NO REASON why representation from the current Libyan leadership cannot work with the opposition leadership, and vice versa, in creating a pathway to a new government, sparing Libyan lives and the stress of a prolonged conflict.

Here's my guess. The doctor did not see hair loss. The girl believes she is losing hair because she has body dysmorphic disorder.

The mother has Munchausen's by proxy syndrome, i.e. she brings in her daughter for fake illnesses. She gives her daughter drugs that will cause symptoms that she can bring her daughter in for. The drugs caused the liver damage.

The medical record will show that the mother brought in the daughter many times with odd symptoms or with no symptoms.
Leg length discrepancy due to adolescence leading to abnormal muscle tension?

A metabolic myopathy caused by a glycogen storage disease with seconday telogen effluvium is the most likely diagnosis. Myopathies may be "presymptomatic" in some cases, whereas in others, such as McArdle's, patients have poor exercise tolerance. This patient doesn't report a history of poor exercise tolerance, though her dad's comment that she just plays the violin suggests that maybe she doesn't exercise too much because she tires quickly. Also, McArdle's may not present until adolescence. Danon disease may also present later, particularly in females. Does she get a "second wind" and did she have a urinalysis?

"It's all about the oil."

On its surface, that would seem like a logical comment. But 95% of the time, it's dead wrong. The reason is very simple if you understand world oil markets (a subject on which virtully every person who posts a remark like that absolutely positively knows nothing).

World oil markets are like any other market: if one supplier is out, you go to another one. Period. Simple. There is no point to our trying to grab Libyan oil. The government doesn't just take it. If our soldiers "control" the source, WE STILL HAVE TO BUY THE FRIGGIN OIL--AT MARKET PRICES!

In addition, can any of you "It's all about the oil" people take a wild guess as to how a dictator like Q or K makes his money? Oh, wait--I know! By SELLING OIL ON THE WORLD MARKET.

So suppose Qadafy says "None of this oil can go to the U.S." Well, heaven forbid! We would then have to buy more oil from Saudi Arabia, Indonesia, Venezuela, Bahrain, Kuwait, Russia ... the list goes on and on. And if Qadafy were selling oil to someone else to fuel his expensive tastes, then that someone else is not bidding against us for all that other oil.

In other words, an embargo doesn't work without a whole lot of fatcat, need-the-money oil producers going along. We don't need to "control" Libya's oil. If it goes on the market, it adds to the supply, and we get the oil we want. Period.

That is how markets work. You don't go to war for oil anymore.

Now if a country were taking over the private property of American oil producing companies (an event we have not seen any reporting on in Libya), then the U.S. government might have to take action to help them. But bombing isn't the way to do that.

This "It's all about the oil" rhetoric is astoundingly stupid. It is not about the oil. It is about getting behind the changes going on in the Middle East. And it is about rescuing hundreds of thousands of ordinary Libyans from the cruelest of insane dictators. Idi Amin had nothing on this guy.

So wake up and stop smearing our leadership withe the ugliness that resides only in your own hearts.

To make a diagnosis you still have to guess.  I would run a test on enzymes of the pancreas. Probably a lack fatty acids or also called vitamin E, estrogen or testosterone.  This could be a pancreatic disorder or hypoglycemia, chronic fatigue, or a thyroid disorder, or dwarfism which all cause hair follicules to die out.  I would also test if she is allergic to shampoo or soap.  Soap and shampoo also cause hair follicules to die out by drying them out.  Oil in place of shampoo might work to treat it.
I guess Becker Muscular Dystrophy

Take heart, Germany!

In another Times article today (http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/24/world/europe/24germany.html?hp), the writers castigate Germany for not hopping on the Libya war bandwagon. But just how "alone" is Germany?

The population of the 10 countries whose Security Council members voted FOR the attack on Libya (based on 2009 population figures):

704 million people.

The population of the 5 countries whose Security Council members DECLINED to vote for the attack on Libya (based on 2009 population figures):

2,904 million people.

“Politics have no relation to morals.” Niccolo Machiavelli

Why should the poor and innocent Qadafi be targeted?

His peaceful actions:
*Initiated murderous attacks on airlines
*Initiated terror attacks against Americas in Germany

* Massaging the Arab people on TV that terrorist are heroes and everything will be done to relies them from jail.
On the reception of the Lockerbie bomber in Libya, Kaddafi son words to the bomber read by a mouth movement expert were
:!!! The killer freedom was on the economical negotiations with UK.

*Funded ,trained and protect Palestinian terrorist groups like the one who killed 36 Israeli civilians, the majority children and women in a bus.
(It is ok- they are Israelis-meaning legitimate targets for killing terrorists, aren't they?)
Moral value to be reviewed!

If a dictator kills many whileOil reach countries support him he is a hero or at least protected

Getting involved with another countries civil war is a big mistake. To make matters worse our own DOD says Libya poses no threat to the USA. We are not even sure who these rebels are yet we are backing them, they could be tied to Al Queda. This move is a major blunder on the Obama Administrations part.
